This loan will be used to purchase household goods such as: plates, cups, glasses, pots, etc.

In the photograph, Nelly is the second person standing on the right. She is grateful for the Kiva lenders for supporting her.

loans.use: purchase household products to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase fertilizers for top dressing her crops so as to get a better harvest

loans.name: Santhiaba Sud 2 Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe a été crée depuis le 26 Aout 2012.Les membres habitent dans le même quartier et ont une bonne cohésion.

Awa l'emprunteur en vedette est âgée de 55ans.Elle est marié et mère de 5 enfants  dont 3 garçons.

Elle fait du petit commerce de tissu.Elle achète des tissus(thioub) par paquet au Mali pour les revendre à Louga.Elle fait cette activité depuis plusieurs années.Elle Fait son activité au marché centrale.

Le crédit est destiné à l'achat des tissus(thioub) 4paquets à 60000f voir 50000f l'un selon la qualité du tissu.Elle n'est pas la seule à faire cette activité,mais elle sa propre clientèle.

Avec les bénéfices,elle compte renforcer son épargne et satisfaire ses besoins.
texts.en:
This group was established on 26th August 2012. The members live in the the same neighbourhood and have a good relationship.



Awa is the leading borrower of this loan and is 55 years old. She is married and has five children, three of which are boys.



She has a small fabric business. She buys fabrics in packets in Mali to sell in Louga. She has had this business for many years. Awa carries out her business in the central market.



The loan is required to buy four packets of fabrics costing between 60000f and 50000f depending on the quality. She is not the only one with this business, but she has her own clientele.


With the profits she hopes to strengthen her savings and satisfy her needs.

loans.use: to buy fabrics

loans.name: Roberto

texts.es: El joven Roberto nació en el año de 1991. Vivió con su familia en la comunidad el Guapinol hasta los 14 años de edad, estudió hasta quinto grado, ya que ayudaba en las labores con sus hermanos en los cultivos de granos básicos. Luego el señor Roberto y su familia se trasladaron  a vivir a Matagalpa. Cuando el señor Roberto tenía 18 años de edad, murió la madre de él a consecuencia de problemas en los riñones fue un golpe duro para él y todos los hermanos. A los 21 años conoció a una muchacha con la cual procreó un niño que actualmente tiene 2 años de edad, pero decidieron separarse, luego de un tiempo conoció a otra muchacha y decidieron estar juntos. Con mucho esfuerzo el señor Roberto logró hacer su casa donde vive junto con su señora, el hijo del señor Roberto no vive con él, sino con los abuelos maternos, pero lo ve de vez en cuando. el señor Roberto trabaja en la agricultura tiene sembrado café en la propiedad y lo asiste bastante para obtener buena producción ya que le deja algunas ganancias y así ha podido comprar algunas herramientas de trabajo. en esta comunidad no hay luz eléctrica es por eso que don Roberto está solicitando un préstamo para la compra de un panel solar y así poder tener luz en su casa que esta recién hecha, y así poder alumbrarse con energía y no con candelas y foco que es con lo que actualmente lo hace. Estaría muy agradecido se le brindan la oportunidad de este préstamo para la compra de este sistema solar.
texts.en:
Roberto is a young man, born in 1991. He lived with his family in the Guapinol community until he was 14 years old, and he attended school until 5th grade. He would help his siblings with field labor, farming basic grains. Then, Roberto and his family moved to live in Matagalpa.

When he was 18 years old, his mother died from kidney problems, which was a hard hit for Roberto and all of his siblings. At 21 years old, he met a girl with whom he had a child, now 2 years old, but they decided to get separated. After some time he met another girl and they decided to be together.

With much effort, Roberto successfully made his house, where he now lives with his woman. His child does not live with him, nor do his maternal grandparents, but he sees them sometimes. Roberto works in agriculture, and has coffee already planted on his property. It helps him greatly to have a good production and makes him some earnings, enabling him to buy some work tools.

In this community there is no electricity, and so Roberto is requesting a loan to buy a solar panel, which will light his recently-made home. It will produce light with energy rather than candles, as he currently has.

Roberto would be very thankful for the opportunity granted by this loan for the solar power system.

loans.use: to install a 100-watt solar panel with 5 lights.

loans.name: Veronicah

texts.en:
Veronicah has finished paying her previous loan. She was able to buy more stock of animal mineral nutrients that boosted her income. She has diversified her business by venturing into fish farming.

She is borrowing a Kiva loan to buy a polythene bag that will help in fish pond repair. She hopes this will boost her business and hence increase her income. She will therefore be able to support her family.

Veronicah is grateful to Kiva and the lenders for the help and support and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: to buy a polythene bag that will help in fish pond repair.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a snooker table for her husband's club.

loans.name: Kamsé Group

texts.fr:
Haoua, âgée de 53 ans mariée mère de 2 enfants. Transformatrice de jus de Rônier appelé « Bandji ». Ce qui fait marcher son activité c’est la qualité du jus.
Elle veut le prêt de 300 000 pour accroitre la production du jus. L’utilité du prêt c’est de pouvoir produire plus de jus pour satisfaire ses clients. Elle a déjà reçu le prêt 1 fois et à rembourser à la date prévue.
texts.en:
Haoua, who is 53 years old, is married and the mother of 2 children. 

She makes juice from the Palmyra palm, called "Bandji." Her business is successful because of the quality of her juice.

She wants a loan of 300,000 francs CFA to increase her production and satisfy her customers. She has already received one loan, and she repaid it on time.

loans.use: to increase her production of juice

loans.name: Waguessé 3 Group

texts.fr:
Safoura est agée de 41 ans, mariée mère de 8 enfants tous scolarisés dont son mari est commerçant. Elle exerce son activité de  vente de légumes depuis 10 ans. Ce qui fait marcher son activité c’est son expérience, son accueil et le respect de ses clients, la différence des prix avec celles des autres.
Elle veut le prêt pour acheter les légumes à 100 000. L’utilité du prêt c’est d’approvisionner son commerce en quantité suffisante pour satisfaire sa clientèle.
Elle à déjà reçu le prêt 1 fois et à rembourser à la date prévue.
texts.en:
Safoura is 41 years old, married, and the mother of eight children, who all go to school. Her husband is a merchant. 

Safoura has worked selling vegetables for 10 years. She has been successful because of her experience, her knowledge, her respect for her customers, and her differences in price. 

Safoura wants this loan to buy vegetables for 100,000 francs CFA. This loan will allow her to stock her business with enough to satisfy her customers. 

She has already received one loan before, and she repaid it on time.

loans.use: to buy vegetables to stock her business

loans.name: Silvia

texts.en:
In this picture, you see Silvia. She is 47 years old and married with two children. 

Silvia lives at La, Ghana. She sells sachet (bagged) water for a living and has been in this business for one year. She sells the water to support her family's expenses. 

One big challenge she faces in the business is limited capital. She does not have enough money to buy more bags of water to sell, so she does not earn much income.

With this loan, Silvia will buy more bags of water to sell. Since there is a higher demand for her water than she can meet, she believes, with more water, she will be able to make more income and support her husband in taking care of their children.

loans.use: To buy sachet (bagged) water to sell and increase income

loans.name: Laura

texts.es:
Laura continúa estudiando psicología. El crédito anterior lo invirtió en el pago de sus mensualidades y seminarios. El pago de sus cuotas fue puntual porque no tuvo problemas en su trabajo. Actualmente se encuentra en la etapa final de su carrera, rindiendo exámenes y exponiendo tareas, “estoy terminando mis estudios, sólo me falta pagar los gastos de elaboración de tesis y pago de titulación…” comenta. Ella cuenta con un gran respeto hacia la vida y el ser humano, es persistente, idealista, dependiente y amable. Su vocación es de servicio. La ventaja de sus actividades es que no se cruzan entre sí, la desventaja es la falta de capital para pagar los trámites finales. Su sueño es ejercer su profesión ella desea realizar el pago de la elaboración de tesis y titulación. Esta es la 2 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 5 años de estudio.
Es por esos motivos que Laura solicita un préstamo para pagar los tramites finales y titulación para ejercer su profesión.
texts.en:
Laura continues to study psychology. She invested the previous loan in paying the tuition and fees. Her loan payments were punctual because she didn't have any problems in her work. Currently, she is in the final stage of her major, taking exams and presenting her work. "I am finishing my studies, I only have to pay the fees for the thesis and to register my degree..." she says. She has a great respect for life and the human being. She is persistent, idealistic, a sales clerk and friendly. Her vocation is service. The advantage of her work is that it doesn't conflict with itself, the disadvantage is the lack of capital to pay for the final paperwork. Her dream is to work in her profession. She wants to pay the thesis fees and to register her degree. She is in her second loan cycle with the institution in her 5 years of study.

For these reasons, Laura asks for a loan to pay the final fees and to register her degree to work in her profession.

loans.use: to pay for the final paperwork and to register her degree to carry out her profession.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: purchase more clothes

loans.name: Lineth Susan

texts.es:
Lineth es una joven mujer de 18 años de edad, soltera, sin hijos, y estudia la carrera de ingeniería ambiental.
Ella es inteligente, perseverante, constante, alegre, feliz y muy responsable. Sus estudios los realiza en una universidad privada ubicada en la zona de irpavi, caracterizado por encontrarse al sur de la ciudad, área residencial. De clima frio y seco con una temperatura que varía durante el día entre 0-12 grados centígrados.
Lineth es de tez morena, ojos obscuros, cabello negro largo lacio, baja estatura, físico robusto, su lengua materna es el Aymará y habla español. Su vida la realiza en casa de sus padres que trabajan independientemente y con sus hermanas que estudian en la escuela, viven en una casa propia construida de ladrillo y cemento que cuenta con agua potable, energía eléctrica y alcantarillado. Ella estudia la carrera de ingeniería ambiental debido a su sensibilidad ante las situaciones medioambientales de su entorno, le gusta trabajar en equipo, resolver problemas, su carácter es de servicio a la comunidad, “estudie en colegio hasta los 17 años y escogí la carrera de ingeniería ambiental…” comenta. La ventaja de sus estudios es su carácter sensible frente al mundo, la desventaja es la falta de capital para el pago de matrícula y equipo de estudio. Su sueño es terminar de estudiar, ella desea pagar la matrícula y comprar equipo de estudio, esta es la 1 secuencia de préstamos con la institución en 1 año que estudia.
Es por esos motivos que Lineth solicita un préstamo para pagar la matrícula de ingeniería ambiental y comprar equipo de estudio.
texts.en:
Lineth is an 18-year-old young woman, single, with no children, and she is studying for a degree in environmental engineering.

She is intelligent, persistent, reliable, cheerful, content and very responsible. She is studying in a private university located in the Irpavi zone, characterized by being to the south of the city, in a residential area. It has a cold and dry climate with temperatures that vary during the day between 0-12 degrees centigrade.

Lineth has dark skin, dark eyes, long straight black hair, is short, has a robust physique, her native language is Aymará and she speaks Spanish. She has her life in her parents' house, who work independently, and with her sisters who go to school. They live in their own house, built of brick and cement which has drinking water, electricity and sewer services. She is studying for a degree in environmental engineering due to her feelings about the environmental situation around her. She likes to work in a team and solve problems. Her character is serving the community "I went to secondary school up to age 17 and I chose a major in environmental engineering..." she says. The advantage of her studies is her sensitive character concerning the world, the disadvantage is the lack of capital to pay tuition and for school supplies. She is in her first loan cycle with the institution in the 1 year she has been a student.

For these reasons, Lineth asks for a loan to pay the tuition for environmental engineering and to purchase school supplies.

loans.use: to pay the tuition in environmental engineering and purchase school supplies.

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is 69 years old. She is married and has one child. She does farming and livestock keeping. She grows cash crops such as maize and vegetables to sell and the business has been profitable.

This is her first loan from VisionFund Kenya. She will use the loan to buy fertilizer and seeds so as to get more farm produce to sell and be able to support her family. She will use the anticipated profits from the expanded business to buy food for the family. Her hopes and dreams for the future are to expand her farming and get more farm produce to sell.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seeds so as to get more farm produce to sell and be able to support her family.

loans.name: Naeku

texts.en:
Naeku is 51 years old. She is married with nine children.

She is a farmer. She has run this business for six years and it has been profitable.

Naeku will be using the loan to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizer, seeds, and manure. She hopes this will help her pay school fees.

Her hope and dream for the future is to expand her farming business.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizer, seeds, and manure

loans.name: Dumar Alberto

texts.en:
Dumar is 50 years old and lives in the municipality of Bello, north of Medellín. He has four children living at home whom he loves very much. They are the reason he always wakes up early to work, to give them the best. He owns a store full of all the products that you can find in a supermarket.That’s why customers prefer him.

He´s always thinking how to improve his store, and how to offer more products so his customers keep coming. But he can't afford to invest more. So he’s asking for a loan to buy more supplies like sodas, pet food and diary products. 

Dumar hopes his store will become successful and help him keep supporting his family. He also wishes he could fix his house because it has some structural problems. You can help this hardworking man to accomplish his dreams with just a loan and a little trust.

loans.use: to buy more supplies like sodas, pet food and diary products.

loans.name: Rosie

texts.en:
As a parent of eight children, Rosie works hard to support her family.

She has a food vending business in the Philippines and earns additional income from vegetable vending. Rosie is borrowing PHP 6,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients for her food production business.

Rosie has been sustaining her business activities through her past one loan from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food production business

loans.name: Yabouyi Group

texts.fr: YAOUMOU est celle qui tient la corne du bélier dans le groupe.C’est une éleveuse d’ovin de nationalité Malienne, âgée de 32 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants dont 2 garçons et 1 fille scolarisés. Elle exerce cette activité d’élevage d’ovin depuis 6 ans.Elle achète ses bétails au marché l’élever et revendre après quelque mois à marché public avec intérêt. Le prêt lui permettra de développer son activité, et le revenu sera consacré à bien nourrir ses enfants, à leurs achetés des chaussures et vêtements, et payer les frais de scolarisation .
texts.en:
Yaoumou is the one who is holding the goat's horn in the photo. She is 32 years old, from Mali, and raises livestock. She is married and the mother of four children-of which three (two sons and one daughter) attend school.

Yaoumou has raised livestock for six years. She buys the livestock at the market, raises them, and then resells them some months later at a public market for a profit. 

This loan will allow her to develop her farming. Earnings will help to feed her children, buy them shoes and clothing, and pay for their school fees.

loans.use: to buy sheep to raise and resell

loans.name: Aventura Group

texts.es:
Es un grupo solidario mixto, conformado por 2 mujeres y un hombre (HERMECINDA ERLINDA, JULIANA y FERMIN ANTONIO) de la etnia miskita de la ciudad de Bilwi, municipio de Puerto Cabezas. Son hombres y mujeres emprendedoras que trabajan día a día con el empeño de lograr el crecimiento de sus pequeños negocios; se organizaron como grupo solidario hace 2 meses para acceder préstamo en Pana Pana. 

Juliana: Es integrante del grupo solidario, es una señora de 49 años de edad, madre soltera de 6 hijos: 5 mayores de edad y el menor de 11 años que estudia su tercer grado de primaria. Vende bastimestos y mariscos en uno de los mercados de la ciudad de Bilwi. Solicita financiamiento para comprar carbón, coco y pescados. Ella con ser una comerciante exitosa
texts.en:
This is a supportive, diverse group comprised of two women and a man (Hermecinda Erlinada, Juliana and Fermin Antonio) of Miskita ethnicity from the city of Bilwi in Puerto Cabezas. These entrepreneurs work everyday with the goal of growing their small businesses. Two month ago, they formed a group in order to access loans from Pana Pana.

Juliana is a member of the group. She is a 49 years old single mother of six (five are adults, and one is 11 years old and in third grade). She sells side dishes and sea food in one of the markets in Bilwi. She is seeking a loan to purchase charcoal, coconuts and fish. She dreams of being a successful businesswoman.

loans.use: purchase charcoal, coconuts and fish.

loans.name: Tsiuri

texts.en:
Tsiuri is 59 years old. She lives in Kobuleti district with her husband and son. The family is involved in agricultural activities. In particular, they have a cow and Tsiuri produces milk products to sell. In addition, they own a plot of agricultural land where they grow nut trees and mandarin trees. As the income is only seasonal, the family decided to start a new business.

The Startup program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables her to get a loan of GEL 3,000. With the received credit, Tsiuri will purchase a car and her husband will serve people as a taxi driver. This will significantly increase the family income and they will be able to improve their living conditions.

Tsiuri awaits your support.

loans.use: to purchase a car for her husband to start a taxi bsuiness.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Chan is a 30-year-old married father with two small children, who lives in the Takeo Province in Cambodia. He is a rice farmer and construction worker. He has cultivated rice since 2008. His wife is 30 years old and she is a factory worker. Chan and his wife can make around USD 13 per day.

Now Chan would like to request a loan to buy more farmland to cultivate rice. This loan will help him make more profit for his family as well as have a better standard of living. In the future, Chan wants to buy more farmland, renovate his house and support his children to earn a higher education.

loans.use: to buy more farmland to cultivate rice

loans.name: Mutua

texts.en:
Mutua is 42 years old. He is married and has five children. He sells cows, goats and donkeys and has been in the business for seven years.

This is his first loan with VisionFund Kenya. He intends to use the loan to buy a donkey and goats to sell. He will use the profit from his business to pay school fees for his children and increase his business capital.

His hopes and dreams for the future are to grow and stabilize the business to generate more income.

loans.use: to buy a donkey and goats to sell

loans.name: Salvaje Group

texts.es:
El grupo solidario Salvaje, está conformado por 3 mujeres emprendedoras (CRISTINA, DELITA y KATHEEN BIANKA), viven en la ciudad de Bilwi; se unieron hace 12 meses con el propósito de trabajar de manera solidaria para poder tener acceso a préstamos en Pana Pana, que les permitiera incrementar el inventario de sus pequeños negocios, mejorar sus ingresos y así mejorar poco a poco las condiciones de vida de sus familias.

KATHEEN BIANKA: Es una señora de 28 años de edad, casada con 2 hijos adolescentes que estudian su primaria. Su esposo es pescador. Con el propósito de tener su propia fuente de ingresos y contribuir con los gastos del hogar y educación de sus hijos, desde hace un año elabora pan de coco y reposterías de manera artesanal en su vivienda de tambo y madera. Solicita financiamiento para comprar insumos: harina, azúcar, levadura, coco, canela, entre otros productos. Ella sueña con mejorar las condiciones de su pequeño negocio y tener vitrinas para exhibir los productos que elabora.
texts.en:
The Salvaje loan group is composed of 3 enterprising women (Cristina, Delita and Katheen Bianka). They live in the city of Bilwi. They got together 12 months ago with the purpose of working integrally to be able to have access to loans in Pana Pana, which would allow them to increase the inventory of their small businesses, improve their earnings and thus improve the living conditions of their families little-by-little.

Katheen Bianka is a 28 year old woman. She is married with 2 young children who are in elementary school. Her husband is a fisherman. With the purpose of having her own income source and contributing to paying the household expenses and her children's education, she started making coconut bread and artesian pastries in her stilt and wood home. She is asking for a loan to buy supplies such as flour, sugar, yeast, coconut, cinnamon, and other products. She dreams of improving the conditions of her small business and having showcases to show the products that she makes.

loans.use: to buy supplies such as flour, sugar, yeast, coconut, cinnamon, and other products.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is 22 years old and the second born in a family of six. He is currently undertaking a course in electrical installation at St Kizito Technical Institute. Junior Achievement Kenya Partnered with St Kizito to provide entrepreneurship and financial literacy skills to the students at St Kizito. 

Patrick joined the training in February 2015. Since he started the training he has been keen to start a business in rearing chicken.  He got a place to establish the chicken run at the school which will enable him to start his chicken rearing project. 

It costs KES 22,000 to build a chicken run which can accommodate 100 chicks. It will cost KES 58,000 for the feed and vaccines for one year. The chickens will start laying eggs from week 19 up to week 84, giving a total of 65 weeks with an average of 45 eggs per day. 

He will start with 50 chicks which will produce 20,475 eggs over a period of 65 weeks, amounting to 682 crates. One crate sells for KES320. This will generate a gross profit margin of KES138,240. He is looking forward to continually adding more chicks to the full capacity of the chicken run. 

He will also sell other products from the project which includes manure and the chickens after they are past their laying age of two years. A loan of KES80,000 will enable Patrick to buy 50 chicks and feed.

loans.use: to purchase chicks and feed.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a married man. He has three children and describes himself as determined. 

He operates a farm where he grows vegetables. His business is located in a fertile place and his primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be pests and harsh weather. 

He will use the Kes 70,000 loan to buy seeds and other farm supplies. He hopes that in the future, he will live a happy life. He will use the anticipated profits to invest in other businesses.

loans.use: to buy seed and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase farm supplies such as fertilizer for maize production.

loans.name: Colinas Group

texts.es:
Este grupo solidario está conformado por 3 mujeres (Lesvia, Jacinta y Catrina) de la etnia miskita de la ciudad de Bilwi, del municipio de Puerto Cabezas. Son mujeres emprendedoras que luchan día a día por hacer crecer sus pequeños negocios de venta de ropa usada y pulpería; se organizaron hace 2 años para acceder a préstamos con garantía solidaria en Pana Pana. Decidieron nombrar al grupo solidario Colinas, porque las condiciones y características del terreno donde viven.

Catrina: Es integrante del grupo solidario, es una señora sonriente y alegre de 32 años de edad, casada con 6 hijos: 4 adolescentes que estudian su primaria y secundaria y 2 menores de edad. Con el propósito de tener su propia fuente de ingresos y contribuir con los gastos del hogar y educación de sus hijos. Recuerda con gran entusiasmo que inicio vendiendo bastimentos de manera ambulante, con una pequeña ayuda económica que le brindo su esposo de C$ 1,500 (Mil Quinientos Córdobas Netos). Gracias a las ganancias percibidas y a los créditos otorgados por PANA PANA y financiados con KIVA, le han permitido diversificar sus productos, actualmente vende ropa usada en un tramo que alquila en uno de los mercados de la Ciudad de Bilwi. Esta solicitando financiamiento para comprar en Managua 2 pacas de ropa usada mixta y de hogar, para venderlas a precios accesibles a su clientela. Ella sueña con tener su propio tramo.
texts.en:
This solidarity group is made up of 3 women (Lesvia, Jacinta, and Catrina) of Miskita ethnicity from the city of Bilwi in the municipality of Puerto Cabezas. They are enterprising women who struggle day to day to grow their small businesses of used clothing sales and a general store. They organized themselves 2 years ago to access loans with a solidarity guarantee through Pana Pana. They decided to name their solidarity group Colinas [Hills] because of the conditions and characteristics of the land where they live.

Catrina is a member of the solidarity group. She is a smiling and cheerful woman, 32 years old, married, with 6 children, 4 adolescents who are in their first and second year and 2 younger children. With the goal of having her own source of income and to contribute to the household expenses and the education of her children, she remembers with great enthusiasm that she began selling supplies as a street vendor, with a little economic support that her husband offered her of C$ 1,500 (one thousands five hundred net córdobas). The earnings she has seen and the loans granted by Pana Pana, and financed with Kiva, have permitted her to diversify her products. Currently she sells used clothing in a spot that she rents in one of the markets in the city of Bilwi. She is asking for a loan to purchase 2 bundles of mixed used clothing and household goods in Managua, to sell them at prices accessible to the customer. She dreams of having her own retail space.

loans.use: to purchase 2 bundles of mixed used clothing and home goods in Managua.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a freezer.

loans.name: Rukia's Group

texts.en:
Rukia, who is in her late 30s, is single with four kids who are still at school.  She has been a food vendor for five years.  She works from 12noon to 11pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.
  
This will be Rukia’s ninth loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to increase the stock in her store and has paid back all her loans successfully. She is happy with the loan and appreciates Kiva for the support of their group. She used the profit to pay school fees, repay the loan, buy a plot of land, purchase a television and cover household expenses. She will use this loan to restock the items in her mamalishe store. She dreams of building her own house.

Rukia will share this loan with her loan group Kampala which consists of six members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to restock items in mamalishe store.

loans.name: Bronce Group

texts.es:
Este grupo solidario está conformado por dos mujeres y un hombre todos muy emprendedores, que se organizaron hace 2 meses, con el propósito de acceder a financiamiento para mejorar sus pequeño negocios incrementando su mercadería y así poder mejorar también sus ingresos que les permita poder cubrir las necesidades básicas de su hogar, asegurar la educación de sus hijos y ampliar sus negocios. Decidieron nombrar al grupo solidario Bronce, porque es un metal precioso y fuerte como los integrantes del grupo.

NEYSI: Es la coordinadora del grupo solidario, es una señora amable, con cualidades de líder, casada, tiene un hijo de 6 años de edad, que estudia su segundo grado de educación primaria. Originaria del municipio de Rosita, desde hace 15 años se traslado a Bilwi a estudiar su carrera universitaria de contabilidad. Con el propósito de contar con su propia fuente de ingresos y contribuir con los gastos del hogar, desde hace 10 años estableció una pequeña pulpería en el corredor de su vivienda de tambo y madera. Solicita financiamiento para comprar: granos básicos, chiverías, entre otros productos. Ella sueña con construir su vivienda de concreto.
texts.en:
This loan group is made up of two women and one man who are all very enterprising. They got together 2 months ago, with the purpose of accessing financing to improve their small businesses, increase their merchandise and, therefore, also improve their incomes. This allows them to be able to cover the basic needs of the home, ensure their children's education, and grow their businesses. They decided to name the group "Bronce (Bronze)" because it is a precious metal and is strong just like the members of the group.

Neysi is the coordinator of the group. She is a friendly woman with qualities of a leader. She is married and has one 6 year old son who is in 2nd grade in elementary school. She is native to the town of Rosita and 15 years ago she moved to Bilwi to study accounting in the university. With the purpose of having her own income source and contributing to the household expenses, she established a small grocery store 10 years ago on the patio of her stilt and wood home. She is asking for a loan to buy basic grains, snacks and other products. She dreams of building a concrete house.

loans.use: to buy basic grains, snacks and other products.

loans.name: Keli

texts.en:
Keli, 53, is a divorced and differently-abled lady from a small village of Khurda district and the mother of two boys. She is an intelligent and skillful woman. Keli has developed and grown her business steadily. She started this business with a small amount of capital. But with her strong foresight and intelligence, she has established her business of selling spices. She has learnt cultivating spices from her mother and grandmother since she was a child. She is the breadwinner of her family and meets all of the expenses of her house and her children.

Keli is requesting a loan of 35,000 INR to purchase organic manures, fertilizers and compost and prepare the land so that she can get quality output. She aspires to build a house and give it for rent to get additional income that she will use to bear her children's higher educational expenditures.

loans.use: to purchase organic manures, fertilizers and compost and prepare the land so that she can get quality output.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is 66 years old and married, supporting eight children. He has been a small-scale farmer for the last seven years, earning an income of KES. 10,000 per month.

He has applied for his first loan of KES. 25,000 from Vision Fund Kenya to purchase farm supplies such as fertilizer for maize production.

He plans to use the profit to repay the loan and buy a cow for milk production. He hopes to eradicate poverty and educate his children.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for maize production.

loans.name: Philip

texts.en:
Philip is 36 years old. He is married with three children. He has had a retail shop for three years. 

He will use the loan to purchase stock for his store, and use the profit to pay school fees for his children. 

His hopes and dreams for the future are to succeed in life and open another business.

loans.use: to purchase stock.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: buy another motorcycle.

loans.name: Malinche Group

texts.es:
Está conformado por tres mujeres luchadoras (María Auxiliadora, Juana María y María Emelina)  que se organizaron hace año y medio, con el propósito de acceder a financiamiento para sus pequeños negocios de chivería, granos básicos, ropa y calzado, mejorar sus ingresos, condiciones de vida, poder cubrir las necesidades básicas de su hogar, asegurar la educación de sus hijos y ampliar sus negocios.

María Auxiliadora: Es integrante del grupo solidario, una mujer alegre, originaria de Puerto Cabezas, tiene 42 años de edad, casada, tiene cuatro hijos: Tres son mayores de edad y la menor de  17 años, estudia su quinto año de secundaria. Con el propósito de apoyar con los gastos del hogar, desde hace 5 años comenzó con su pequeña pulpería en su vivienda, también vende frito y enchiladas, que los vende en uno de los colegios públicos de la ciudad de Bilwi. Solicita financiamiento para comprar: chiverías, gaseosas, granos básicos, insumos e ingredientes para la elaboración de frito y enchiladas. Su sueño es llegar a tener un comedor  que ofrezca más comodidad a sus clientes, pueda vender más y así generar más ingresos para mejorar la calidad de vida su familia.
texts.en:
This group is formed by 3 persistent women (María Auxiliadora, Juana María, and María Emelina). They united a year and a half ago with the goal of acquiring a loan for their small businesses selling snacks, basic grains, clothing, and footwear, in order to increase their income, improve their living conditions, cover basic household expenses, ensure education for their children, and expand their businesses.

María Auxiliadora is a member of this supportive group. She is a cheerful woman from Puerto Cabezas. She is 42 years old and married, and has four children. Three are adults, and one is 17 years old, studying in her 5th year of high school.

With the goal of helping with the household expenses, 5 years ago María Auxiliadora started a small store in her house. She also sells fried snacks and enchiladas, which she sells in one of the public schools in the city of Bilwi.

She is requesting a loan to buy snacks, drinks, basic grains, foods, and ingredients for fried snacks and enchiladas. Her dream is to have a restaurant that offers more comfort to her customers, where she can sell more and generate more income, improving her family's quality of life.

loans.use: buy snacks, drinks, basic grains, foods, and ingredients for fried snacks and enchiladas.

loans.name: Cañaveral Group

texts.es:
Es un grupo solidario mixto, está conformado por 2 hombres y una mujer emprendedora, viven en la comunidad de San Miguel, del municipio de Puerto Cabezas. Se unieron hace 2 meses con el propósito de trabajar de manera solidaria para poder acceder a préstamos en Pana Pana  para poder tener la oportunidad de mejorar sus pequeños negocios de venta de granos básicos, y así mejorar la calidad de vida de sus familias.

SINFORIANO: Es el coordinador del grupo solidario, es un señor luchador y amable, casado con 4 hijos menores de edad. Su esposa trabaja en elaboración de productos lácteos: queso, cuajada, crema. Con el propósito de sacar adelante a su familia y tener su propia fuente de ingresos, estableció una pequeña pulpería en su vivienda de tambo y madera. Esta solicitando financiamiento para viajar a la ciudad de Bilwi y comprar: granos básicos, chiverías, entre otros productos. Sueña con tener un negocio prospero.
texts.en: This is a mixed solidarity group. It is formed by two men and an enterprising woman. They live in the community of San Miguel, Municipality of Puerto Cabezas. Two months ago, they came together with the purpose of working jointly to access loans in Pana Pana so they would have the opportunity of improving their small businesses and the quality of life of their families. Sinforiano is the coordinator of the solidarity group. He is a hardworking and kind man, married with four younger children. His wife works making dairy products: cheese, curd, cream. With the purpose of making his family prosper and  having his own source of income, he established a small grocery store in his stilt and wooden house. He is requesting a loan to travel to the city of Bilwi and buy basic grains, dairy products, among other products. He dreams of having a successful business.

loans.use: to buy basic grains, dairy products, among other products.

loans.name: Altamira Group

texts.es:
Este grupo solidario está conformado por tres mujeres (Flor de Maria, Romelia y Berna Jhomary), las tres son miskitas que viven en Bilwi, en el municipio de Puerto Cabezas. Son mujeres emprendedoras que luchan día a día por hacer crecer sus pequeños negocios de venta de frito, chiverías y comercialización de pescado; se organizaron recientemente para acceder a préstamos con garantía solidaria en Pana Pana.

Flor de María: Es la coordinadora del grupo solidaria Altamira, es una joven luchadora de 26 años de edad, casada con 3 hijos: El mayor de 7 años de edad estudia su primer grado de primaria y dos menores de edad. Con el propósito de tener su propia fuente de ingresos y contribuir con los gastos en el hogar, vende frito y enchiladas en uno de los colegios públicos de la ciudad de Bilwi. Solicita financiamiento para comprar: chiverías, gaseosas, granos básicos, insumos e ingredientes para la elaboración de frito y enchiladas. Ella sueña con establecer una pulpería en su vivienda de tambo y madera.
texts.en:
This lending group is made up of three women (Flor de Maria, Romelia, and Berna Jhomary) of Miskita descent who live in the city of Bilwi in Puerto Cabezas. These women are entrepreneurs who strive everyday to grow their small businesses that sell fried foods, snacks and fish. They organized recently in order to access loans from Pana Pana.

Flor de Maria is the coordinator for the Altamira lending group. This young fighter is 26 years old, married, and has three children. Her eldest son is seven years old and is in first grade, and the younger two are not yet in school. With the goal of having her own source of income and contributing to the household finances, she sells fried foods and enchiladas in one of the public schools in Bilwi.

She is seeking a loan to purchase snacks, sodas, basic grains, and supplies and ingredients to make fried foods and enchiladas. She dreams of opening a grocery store in her wooden stilt house.

loans.use: purchase snacks, sodas, basic grains, and supplies and ingredients to make fried foods and enchiladas.

loans.name: Serlyn

texts.en: Serlyn is from Bohol, Philippines. She is a 22-year-old woman and has no children. Her partner is a farmer and a habal-habal driver (a motorcycle with extended an seat to accommodate more passengers in a row, so called because of the seat) while Serlyn is engaged in running a sari-sari store business. She has been doing this for two years. She is asking for a loan to buy assorted stocks such as biscuits, chips, canned goods, noodles, spices, toiletries, sugar, coffee, soft drinks and drinking liquor. In the future, Serlyn dreams to increase her livelihood. With that, she works hard to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy biscuits, chips, canned goods, noodles, spices, toiletries, sugar, coffee, soft drinks and drinking liquor

loans.name: Jhonie

texts.en:
Jhonie is a motorcycle driver from Bohol, Philippines. He is a 43-year-old man and has a six-year-old daughter. His wife is a nurse attendant.

Jhonie dreams of becoming a businessman in the future. He works hard to have capital to start a business. As for now, he owns a motorcycle and is asking for a loan for a new tire, gasoline and other maintenance like changing oil. He has been doing this for fifteen years to earn a living.

loans.use: to buy a tire, gasoline and oil.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is a 28-year-old married man who has operated a retail shop for two years.

This is his first loan from VisionFund Kenya. He will use the loan to maize flour, sugar, rice, salt, cooking oil, and other items.

He will use profits from the expanded business to purchase food for the family. His hopes and dreams for the future are to have a financially stable business.

loans.use: to buy maize flour, sugar, rice, salt, cooking oil, and other items.

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en:
Godfrey is 28 years old, married and supports four children. He has been a small-scale farmer for the last four years, earning an income of KES 10,000 per month.

He has applied his first loan of KES 25,000 from Vision Fund Kenya to purchase farm supplies such as fertilizer growing maize.

He plans to use the profit to repay the loan and buy a cow for milk production. He hopes to eradicate poverty and educate his children.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies such as fertilizer maize production.

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is 61 years old. He is married and supports four children. He has been a small-scale farmer for the last four years, earning an income of KES 10,000 per month.

He has applied for his first loan of KES 25,000 from Vision Fund Kenya to purchase farm supplies such as fertilizer maize production.


He plans to use the profit to repay the loan and buy a cow for milk production. He hopes to eradicate poverty and educate his children.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizer for maize production.

loans.name: Nelli

texts.en:
Nelli is from the city of Vanadzor city in the Lori region. She is thankful for her two previous Kiva loans. She requests a new loan with Kiva and Nor Horizon.

Nelli is married and has a daughter and a son. She has 25 years of pedagogical experience in education and is devoted to her work. She teaches with great love and care. She also tutors her mathematics students at her house who will have entrance exams.

Nelli will use the loan to furnish a dedicated tutoring room for her private students so that the learning process for her pupils will be more productive and concentrated.

loans.use: to furnish a dedicated tutoring room for her private courses.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
As a married mother of five children, Mary works hard to support her family.

She has a business buying and selling fruits and vegetables in the Philippines. Mary is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to buy more fruits and vegetables to sell to customers.

Mary has been sustaining her business activities through her past 14 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more fruits and vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more beans and maize to sell.

loans.name: Muqqadas

texts.en:
MUQQADAS is 24, living with her spouse and four children in the area of Lahore, Pakistan. Her husband is a milkman by trade; he sells milk in the market. His customers like to buy fresh, delicious milk from his shop. His monthly net income is too low to meet the household needs because there are too many competitors in the market.

Due to his milk quality and low reasonable rates, many of the customers like to buy milk from him. He wants to increase the supply of milk on a daily basis by buying an additional cow. He has savings but not enough to purchase a cow.

Therefore, MUQQADAS has requested a loan from Kiva’s field partner BRAC Pakistan, so that her husband is able to buy a cow.

MUQQADAS is very happy to receive this loan. She thanks Kiva and field partner, BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to buy a cow for her husband's milk business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to help fix her son's lathe.

loans.name: Otoño Group

texts.es:
Este grupo solidario está conformado por dos mujeres y un hombre todos muy emprendedores, que se organizaron hace 4 años, con el propósito de acceder a financiamiento para mejorar sus pequeño negocios incrementando su mercadería y así poder mejorar también sus ingresos que les permita poder cubrir las necesidades básicas de su hogar, asegurar la educación de sus hijos y ampliar sus negocios.

Marlon Antonio: Es integrante del grupo solidario, un joven luchador de 28 años de edad, casado con un hijo de 12 años de edad, estudia su sexto grado de primaria. Su esposa estudia su carrera universitaria. Se traslado al municipio de Puerto Cabezas, para apoyar a las comunidades afectadas por el huracán Felix, hace 7 años, como voluntario de una ONG. Con el propósito de sacar adelante a su familia y contar con una fuente de financiamiento vende de manera ambulante cosméticos, sabanas, cuadros, fotografías enmarcadas, entre otros productos de uso del hogar. Esta solicitando financiamiento para comprar en Managua más productos y venderlos a precios accesibles a su clientela. El sueña con tener un tramo y vender electrodomésticos.
texts.en:
This loan group is composed of two women and one man who are all very enterprising. They got together 4 years ago with the purpose of accessing funding to improve their small business, increase their merchandise, and also be able to improve their incomes, which allows them to cover the basic necessities of their homes, ensure their children's education and grow their businesses.

Marlon Antonio is a member of the loan group. He is a young, determined 28 year old. He is married and has a 12 year old son, who is in the 6th grade. His wife is in college. He moved to the town of Puerto Cabezas to support the communities affected by Hurricane Felix 7 years ago, as a volunteer of ONG. With the purpose of raising his family and counting on a funding source, he sells cosmetics, bed sheets, picture frames, framed pictures and other products for household use, on the street. He is asking for funding to buy more products in Managua to sell them at affordable prices to his customers. He dreams of having a market stall and selling appliances.

loans.use: to buy products in Managua: cosmetics, bed sheets, picture frames, framed pictures and other products for household use.

loans.name: Sana

texts.en:
Sana is an active borrower of BRAC Pakistan. She lives with her one child and husband in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. Her husband is the guardian of her family. He has been running a mobile shop for the past 8 years.

Sana's husband wants to purchase different types of mobile accessories for his business purpose, but due to insufficient financial means, her husband is unable to purchase these accessories. Therefore, Sana has applied for a Kiva loan from field partner BRAC Pakistan. With the help of this loan, she’ll enable her husband to purchase relevant items for his business purpose so that he can earn more income to manage his business and household.

Sana is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to purchase accessories and other items for her husband's mobile shop.

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Salma is a 40 year old woman and mother of five sons and two daughters living in a small town of Lahore Pakistan. Her husband runs a photocopy shop which was doing well but due to a lack of the latest machinery the customers who used to visit his shop are now going to far off shops in the market. There they get their photocopies done in no time. So her husband has decided that he will replace his machine with the latest one to regain his lost customers.

Salma applied for the loan so that her husband can regain the profits which he used to bring home a while ago. Salma will be thankful to Kiva and its field partner BRAC Pakistan

loans.use: to replace her husband's photocopy machine with a new one to regain his customers.

loans.name: Kurbonkhon

texts.en:
Qurbonkhon is a light-hearted woman. She was born in the northern part of Tajikistan in 1995. She is living in a small city with her family. She is single and lives with her parents.

Qurbonkhon is a third-year student at the university. She is a capable, goal-oriented, and skillful girl. At the same time as her studies, she does a business of sewing traditional women's dresses. She wants to graduate from her studies with excellence and be in the profession of her major.

She wishes to be helpful to her parents and support them in having a better standard of living. She is asking for financial support from Kiva lenders to pay her higher education costs at the university. She wishes to be understood and supported.

loans.use: to pay her higher education costs of the university.

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en: Luisa is from Bohol, Philippines. She has been engaged in hog-raising for 11 years. She is a 53-year-old woman with two children. Her husband is a caretaker of a fishpond and works hard to provide for the needs of their family. Luisa is asking for a loan of PHP 6,000 to buy piglets and feed. In the future she wishes to improve their livelihood to have a better means of living.

loans.use: to buy piglets and feed.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is married and has three children. For the past four years, she has sold vegetables and fruit to earn a living. She sells to locals from her stall, which is located in a busy area. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient capital.

Elizabeth has taken out and successfully repaid a prior loan through Kiva's field partner, SMEP Microfinance Bank. She has now applied for a KES 15,000 loan to buy additional vegetables and fruit to sell.

loans.use: to buy additional vegetables and fruit to sell.

loans.name: El Buen Samaritano Group

texts.es:
Este grupo solidario está conformado por cuatro mujeres, todas son de la etnia miskita, de la comunidad de Kuakil, municipio de Puerto Cabezas. Son mujeres emprendedoras que luchan día a día por hacer crecer sus pequeños negocios; se organizaron recientemente para gestionar préstamos con garantía solidaria en Pana Pana. 

ZULEMA: Es integrante del grupo solidario, es una joven jovial de 25 años de edad, casada con 2 hijos menores de edad. Con el propósito de tener su propia fuente de ingresos y contribuir con los gastos del hogar, está solicitando su primer financiamiento para comprar cerdos lechones, engordarlos y comercializarlos. Ella sueña con sembrar hortalizas y granos básicos.
texts.en:
This loan group is composed of four women. They are all of the Miskito ethnicity, from the community of Kuakil, in the town of Puerto Cabezas. They are enterprising women who fight day-by-day to make their small businesses grow. They got together recently to manage loans with integrity in Pana Pana.

Zulema is a member of the loan group. She is a cheerful, young, 25 year old woman, and is married with two young children. With the purpose of having her own income and contributing to the household expenses, she is asking for her first loan to buy pigs and piglets to fatten and sell. She dreams of planting vegetables and basic grains.

loans.use: to buy pigs and piglets to fatten and sell.

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
Ana from West Fairview Quezon City, Philippines is a 40-year-old business woman. She runs a shoe business for different footwear such as doll shoes, sandals and slippers. She has been in business for two years. She earns around PHP 33,000 each month and sells items at the Fairview Center Mall. She dreams of having another branch of her business for additional income and profit.  She has children in school, which is the reason she’s striving for the business’ success to pay for school expenses and other expenditures. 

Ana doesn’t have any employees to watch over the business. It’s just her managing it. However she’s planning to hire an employee if given a chance establish another store. She’s just a new member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) and plans to apply for a loan of PHP 30,000 to buy 20 dozen doll shoes, and 5 dozen sandals and slippers. She believes that CCT will help her with her business since, in addition to financial support, they also do seminars and lectures for aspiring entrepreneurs where she can get ideas and marketing strategies for the business.

Ana believes that if you want success to come, you need God to be your greatest foundation. She is consistent in attending a weekly fellowship group for CCT partners that consists of 15 to 30 members where she gains spiritual strength from members' life changing testimony, shares her own experience of God’s love, pays micro finance loans and hears God’s word that is conveyed to them every week.

loans.use: To buy stocks of footwear.

loans.name: Ishaku

texts.en: Ishaku is a Babban Gona farmer from Jalawa Village. He joined Babban Gona so that he could realize better yields on his farm. Since joining Babban Gona, Ishaku no longer has to worry about having inadequate income to pay for his children's school fees. Through Babban Gona’s input loan he will have access to top of the range farm inputs such as fertilizers, herbicides and improved seeds that will help him earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average in Nigeria. This will see him increase his income considerably. This season Ishaku has ambitious plans to harvest 20 bags of maize. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Ishaku now has the opportunity to move into a better home with his family.

loans.use: to purchase improved farm inputs that will increase farm yields.

loans.name: Maryamu

texts.en:
Maryamu is a Babban Gona maize farmer from Gidan Danlami Village. Maryamu joined Babban Gona to increase her wealth. 

Through Babban Gona’s input loan, Maryamu will have access to the best farm inputs in the market such as fertilizers, herbicides and improved seeds that will help herearn yields of up to 30 bags of maize/ hectare, double the Nigerian national average of 14 bags of maize.  This season, Maryamu has grand plans to harvest 15 bags. This will see her increase her household income considerably. Thanks to Babban Gona's support, Maryamu now has the opportunity to increase her yields and income and use her extra earnings to build a house/ renovate her house.

loans.use: To purchase improved farm inputs that will increase farmer’s yields

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy new clothing in Managua.

loans.name: Ovejas Group

texts.es:
Este grupo solidario está conformado por dos mujeres y un hombre todos muy emprendedores, que se organizaron hace 2 meses, con el propósito de acceder a financiamiento para mejorar sus pequeño negocios de venta de bastimento, ropa usada y productos básicos y así poder mejorar también sus ingresos que les permita poder cubrir las necesidades básicas de su hogar, asegurar la educación de sus hijos y ampliar sus negocios.

BENJAMIN: Es integrante del grupo solidario, es un señor luchador de 34 años de edad, casado, con 5 hijos que cursan su primaria y secundaria. Con el propósito de tener su propia fuente de ingresos y sacar adelante a su familia. Su hermana le apoyo con dos 2 pacas de ropa de usada para que iniciara su pequeño negocio, gracias a las ganancias percibidas, le han permitido tener su propio tramo e incrementar el inventario de sus productos. Solicita financiamiento para comprar en Managua 2 pacas de ropa usada. Sueña con construir su vivienda de concreto.
texts.en:
This supportive group is made up of two women and one man, all of them very entrepreneurial.  They organized 2 months ago with the purpose of accessing financing to improve their small businesses of selling provisions, used clothing and basic products.  In this way they would be able to improve their earnings which would allow them to cover the necessary household expenses, secure the education of their children and expand their businesses.

Benjamin is a member of this supportive group.  He is a determined, 34-year-old man.  He is married and has 5 children who are attending primary and secondary school.  With the purpose of having his own source of income and moving his family forward, his sister helped him with 2 bundles of used clothing so that he could begin his small business.  His earnings have permitted him to have his own stall and to increase the inventory of his products.  He is requesting a loan to buy 2 bundles of used clothing in Managua.  He dreams of building his house of concrete.

loans.use: to buy 2 bundles of used clothing in Managua

loans.name: Piyainu Lup Group

texts.en:
Imem lives with her family in the Thoubal district of Manipur. She is a mother of 3 children. The responsibility of managing the household and taking care of the family lies with her and her husband. The income earned by her husband is not sufficient to take care of the household expenses. She started a business of her own and is happy to contribute 3,500 INR to the household income every month. She believes that she can contribute more if she expands her inventory. She does not want to fall short of funds when it comes to educating her children.

Imem leads a group of 5 women who need a loan to increase their earning by expanding their respective businesses. Ibetombi, Rasheshori, Shama and Pramo run weaving businesses. The loan will help them to expand their businesses. They are grateful to their lenders.

loans.use: to expand her business and sell detergent powder, soap, and cereal.

loans.name: Noong Het 17 Group

texts.en:
On is a 29-year-old Thai married woman with two boys aged 10 and 3. She lives with her husband and children in a Thai ethnic traditional house in a village where most of residents make an income from agricultural. Like other villagers, On and her husband work very hard to grow rice and also raise chickens, ducks, and buffalo. On trades agriculture products in the market to earn extra income.

This is the fifth time that On has taken a loan from the Anh Chi Em Program and she will use the loan to buy piglets and food for the pigs. She hopes that her investment will go well, increase production, and bring good income for her family.

On dreams that her children will have a bright future and escape from the vicious circle of poverty. In the picture, she stands at the first from the right.

loans.use: to buy piglets and food for the pigs

loans.name: Pukhree Achouba Group

texts.en:
Sanahal runs a vegetable vending business in Manipur. She needs a loan to expand her business. With the loan she will purchase and sell a wider variety of vegetables like cabbage, brinjal (eggplant), cauliflower, tomatoes, etc. She hopes to earn Rs. 600 more per month if she expands her business.

She is a mother of two children and she works hard to sustain her family. She wants to secure her children’s futures. She believes that the increase in the income generating capacity due to the expansion would allow her to do that.

Sanahal is joined by four women - Robita, Shakmacha, Ibecha and Remika - from the same village in Manipur. They too seek a loan to expand their businesses so they can contribute more to the family income. As the current income from their respective businesses was not enough to maintain their family expenses, they decided to form a group and apply for a loan.

They are grateful to their lenders.

loans.use: To expand her vegetable vending business

loans.name: Elizabeth Ngum

texts.en:
Elizabeth Ngum is married and blessed with two children. She lives in a four-bedroom house in Bamenda, in the northwest region of Cameroon. She will use this loan to buy plantains, bananas, firewood, fertilizer, seeds, palm oil, groundnut oil, plates, spoons, and hire human labour. The fact that she has faced many challenges in life, which are the death of her loved ones, ill health of family members, and armed robbery attacks, has made life so difficult for her. She was motivated to become a member of GHAPE by her friends and relatives. She joined GHAPE in 2009. She has successfully borrowed and repaid loans three times. 

The profit from this loan will help her to settle her bills, provide some basic food for the family, pay for her family’s medication and plough back some of the profit. She prefers GHAPE loans because of low interest rates, convenient time of repayment and the sociability of members towards each other.

She knows her business is going to succeed because she has been doing it for a long time, the demand for food is increasing, and she has a good business site. With this business activity the community will benefit from quality food, moderate prices, reduce the distance to market and have food available on time.

loans.use: To buy plantains, bananas, firewood, fertilizer, seeds, palm oil, groundnut oil, plates, spoons and hire human labour

loans.name: Suh

texts.en:
Suh is married and blessed with two children. They all live in a two bedroom house in the North West Region of Cameroon. She has faced so many difficulties in life, which have been the sickness, death and inadequate finance to start up a business of her own and cater for her family's needs. She was motivated by her friends to join GHAPE. She became a member of GHAPE in 2014 and she has taken and repaid Empowerment Credit once. 

 With this new loan requested, she will buy beans, flour, cocoyam, rice, plantains, chicks and pay her rent. She holds a positive view of this business succeeding because she has been in the restaurant business and agricultural field for a long time. With this business activity, the community will benefit from her activity, she will provide food for the population and manure for gardeners in the local community.

With the profit made from this loan, she is planning to expand her business by buying more piglets and increase the size by buying more food stuff, she will pay her children's school fees and save some in order to undertake a bigger investment. She prefers a GHAPE loan because of low interest rates, convenient repayment intervals and also the members are trained in marketing and management skills before the loans are disbursed.

loans.use: To buy beans, flour, cocoyam, rice, plantains, chicks and to pay the rent.

loans.name: Fénix Group

texts.es:
El grupo Fénix está integrado por once personas cuyas características fundamentales son la iniciativa, responsabilidad, trabajo y el amor que sienten por el campo. Así, mientras la tierra es quien los provee de maíz, arroz, frijol, yuca o camote; la ganadería lo hace de leche, carne y otros productos.
   El nombre del grupo fue elegido por la manera extraordinaria en que el ave fénix renace de sus cenizas, para ellos, si sufren algún tropiezo  se levantan en inician de nuevo con mayor fuerza. Ellos son: Miriam quien se dedica a la sastrería; Claudia, bisutería; Zenaida, costura, comida y productos naturistas; Irma, cosméticos; María C., artículos decorativos; María L., abarrotes; María G., zapatos; Minerva, taller mecánico mientras que María J., Victoria y Eduvigez manejan una estética.
   Miriam es una persona de carácter fuerte y objetivos claros, es madre soltera de una niña y una adolescente: “por mis hijos decidí auto emplearme para ofrecerles lo mejor pues para ellos soy padre y madre”  comenta. Desde hace 17 años se ha dedicado al oficio de costurera, inició a la edad de 15 años remendando los pantalones de sus vecinos, poniendo sierres o haciendo dobladillos. De igual forma, recuerda con alegría que cuando era niña tomaba la ropa de su padre, tijeras y agujas y con ello confeccionaba ropa para sus muñecas. Posteriormente su madre le enseño la técnica correcta y al alcanzar la mayoría de edad estudió una carrera técnica como modista.Por otro lado, los fines de semana trabaja con sus padres en la elaboración de barbacoa de res, pollo o puerco ya que este platillo es tradicional en su comunidad. Con las ganancias que obtiene solventa los gastos del hogar y la educación de sus hijos. 
   El préstamo que ha solicitado lo invertirá en la compra de tela, bies, alfileres, botones, cierres, aguja e hilos para comenzar a confeccionar uniformes escolares para el próximo ciclo escolar. “Gracias por cada préstamo otorgado pues, como el ave fénix, logramos resurgir con nuestras actividades o incrementar nuestra productividad” con estas palabras Miriam agradece la confianza y el apoyo de VFMéxico.
*La fotografía fue tomada fuera de la casa de Miriam quien viste blusa color verde y pantalón color beige. Los niños que se observan son hijos de Eduvigez.
texts.en:
Revised 

The Grupo Felix consists of eleven people whose main characteristics are initiative, responsibility, work and the love they feel for the countryside. The land provides corn, rice, beans, cassava or sweet potato while livestock provide milk, meat and other products.

The group's name was chosen as, like a phoenix rising from the ashes, if they suffer a setback they will rise again with greater force. They are: Miriam who is earns a living in tailoring; Claudia, jewellery; Zenaida, sewing, food and health food products; Irma, cosmetics; Mary C., decorative items; Maria L., groceries; Maria G., shoes; Minerva, a garage while Mary J., Victoria and Eduvigez run a beautician's.

Miriam has a strong character, clear objectives and is a single mother with a young girl and a teenager; "for my children I decided to become self-employed in order to provide them with the best as I am their father and mother," she says.

For 17 years she has been earning a living as a seamstress. She began at the age of 15 mending trousers for her neighbours by attaching zips or taking up hems. Also, she remembers with joy being a child and taking her father's clothes, scissors and needles and making clothes for her dolls. Later her mother taught her the correct technique and when she was older she trained in order to be a dressmaker. 

She also works on weekends helping her parents in the preparation of barbecue beef, chicken or pork which are traditional dishes in their community. The profits made help cover the household expenses and the education of their children.

She is applying for a loan in order to buy fabric, bias binding, pins, buttons, zips, needles and thread in order to begin making school uniforms for the next school year. "Thanks for every loan granted as, like the phoenix, we succeed in reinvigorating our activities and increasing our productivity". With these words Miriam gives thanks for the confidence and support of VFMéxico.

* The photograph was taken outside the home of Miriam who is wearing a green blouse and beige pants. The children in the picture are the children of Eduvigez.

loans.use: to buy fabric, bias binding, pins, buttons, zips, needles and thread.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more fish, grilling tools, and a small fan.

loans.name: Aidah

texts.en:
Aidah is 36 years old and lives in the town of Nansana in the Kampala region of Uganda. She is married and has two children with one of them currently in school. For the past four years, Aidah has been working hard to manage her clothing business, which deals in garments.

To help expand her business, Aidah has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more materials, and will help Aidah to generate greater profits and increase her income. Aidah hopes that in the future she will be able to own a wholesale shop.

Aidah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Aidah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more materials.

loans.name: Marichu

texts.en:
Marichu is a 42-year-old woman from Bohol, Philippines. She is married and has four children, three girls and one boy. Her husband is an electrician while she raises hogs. She has been in this business for two years. 

Marichu and her husband work hard to have a better life. Thus, she is asking for a loan to buy piglets and feed to help them improve their livelihood. In the future, she wants to expand her hog-raising business to improve her profitability.

loans.use: to buy piglets and feed.

loans.name: Saitoti

texts.en:
Saitoti is 25 years old. He is single with no children. He has had a sheep business for six years. 

He will be using the loan to purchase more sheep and hopes this will help him expand the business. His hopes and dreams for the future are to open another business.

loans.use: to purchase more sheep to help him expand the business.

loans.name: Rosalyn

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Rosalyn works hard to support her family. She has a food vending business in the Philippines, and earns additional income from a general store. 

Rosalyn, who has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF, is borrowing PHP 9,000.00 to buy ingredients for her food vending business. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food vending business

loans.name: Armine

texts.en:
This nice lady is 31 years old. Her name is Armine and she hopes she will manage to have her third Kiva loan. She lives with her husband and two daughters in Kapan city of Syunik region. 

Armine has a higher education. Her husband works at a private company as a chief accountant. Their children are school-aged. Starting in 2005 Armine has been selling men's and women's clothes at the city’s wholesale market. Her stall’s clothes assortment is great, colorful and very fashionable so she has no lack of customers. 

She mentions that she already knows the taste of all her customers and has clothes suited to all of them, no matter of which size they are. Armine is very polite in her service. With the coming of summer she managed to have a good sale of summer clothing and now she is short on merchandise. She needs this loan to refresh her summer stock and purchase an autumn clothes collection.

loans.use: to buy a summer and autumn clothes collection for her stall.

loans.name: Haruna

texts.en:
Haruna is a Babban Gona farmer from Gidan Village. he joined Babban Gona so that he could realise better yields on his farm. Since joining Babban Gona, Haruna no longer has to worry about having inadequate income to feed his family and children. 

Through Babban Gona’s input loan he will have access to top of the range farm inputs such as fertilisers, herbicides and improved seeds that will help him earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize/ hectare, double the national average in Nigeria.  This will see increase him increase his income considerably.  This season Haruna has ambitious plans to harvest 60 bags of maize. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Haruna now has the opportunity to ensure that all his children get a post secondary education.

loans.use: To purchase improved farm inputs that will increase farmer’s yields

loans.name: Habila

texts.en:
Habila is a Babban Gona maize farmer from Gayya Village. Habila joined Babban Gona to create a better life for his children. In the past, Habila  suffered from poor yields that crippled hisability to feed his family and children. 

Now that he has joined Babban Gona, Habila  has the chance to attain yields of up to 30 bags of maize/hectare, double the national average in Nigeria and earn an income of up to $2,000/hectare. Through Babban Gona’s input loan, he will have access to high-quality farm inputs such as fertilizers, herbicides, and improved seeds that will increase his yields and income considerably. With ambitious goals of harvesting 10 bags of maize this year, Habila can now ensure that his children get a post secondary education.

loans.use: To purchase improved farm inputs that will increase farmer’s yields

loans.name: Mother Kevin School

texts.en:
Greetings from Uganda! This is Francis. He is the deputy head teacher of Mother Kevin Primary School, a mixed school in the urban area of Kiwanga in Kampala with 700 students.

Mother Kevin School has requested a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining a UV water filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students. The school does not currently have access to consistent clean drinking water and therefore has to spend a considerable portion of its budget on firewood, which is used to boil water for the children. Installing a water filtration system will therefore save the school money in the long-term, as the cost of firewood will be reduced. The loan will enable the school to purchase a UV water treatment system with a 450-litre tank, which will be big enough to store clean drinking water for the students every day.

Mother Kevin School will repay their loan from their school fees, which they collect each term. Francis ultimately hopes that having access to safe drinking water will improve his students’ concentration and attendance by reducing the number of children that fall sick from water-borne diseases, as well as increase the number of students coming to the school.

loans.use: to purchase a water filtration system to provide clean drinking water for its students.

loans.name: Sule

texts.en: Sule is a Babban Gona farmer from Masama Village. He joined Babban Gona so that he could realize better yields on his farm. Since joining Babban Gona, Sule no longer has to worry about having inadequate income to feed his family and children. Through Babban Gona’s input loan he will have access to top-of-the-range farm inputs such as fertilizers, herbicides and improved seeds that will help him earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize/ hectare, double the national average in Nigeria.  This will see increase him increase his income considerably.  This season Sule has ambitious plans to harvest 40 bags of maize. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Sule now has the opportunity to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

loans.use: To purchase improved farm inputs that will increase farmers' yields

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is a Babban Gona farmer from Masama Village. he joined Babban Gona so that he could realise better yields on his farm. Since joining Babban Gona, Ibrahim no longer has to worry about having inadequate income to increase his farmland. 

Through Babban Gona’s input loan he will have access to top of the range farm inputs such as fertilisers, herbicides and improved seeds that will help him earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize/ hectare, double the national average in Nigeria.  This will see increase him increase his income considerably.  This season Ibrahim has ambitious plans to harvest 40 bags of maize. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Ibrahim now has the opportunity to buy maize grinding machines.

loans.use: To purchase improved farm inputs that will increase farmer’s yields

loans.name: Gasparin Group

texts.es:
Este grupo solidario está conformado por 3 mujeres emprendedoras, pertenecen a la etnia miskita, viven en  Bilwi, municipio de Puerto Cabezas. Hace 12 meses se organizaron en grupo solidario con el propósito de trabajar de manera solidaria para acceder a préstamos en Pana Pana y tener la oportunidad de mejorar sus pequeños negocios de venta de mariscos, mejorar sus ingresos y así mejorar la calidad de vida de sus familias. Decidieron nombrar al grupo solidario Gasparin, en honor a un ángel.

BEKSI: Es integrante del grupo solidario Gasparin, tiene 24 años de edad, casada con 3 hijos: 2 adolescentes que estudian su primaria y un recién nacido. Su esposo trabaja de forma informal, como albañil. Con el propósito de tener su propia fuente de ingresos y contribuir con los gastos del hogar y educación de sus hijos, estableció una pequeña pulpería y venta de bastimento en un tramo que tiene en uno de los mercados de la ciudad de Bilwi. Esta solicitando financiamiento para diversificar su negocio y vender pescados y marisco. Ella sueña con tener una miscelánea.
texts.en:
This solidarity group was made by three enterprising women from the Miskito people. They live in Bilwi, a municipality of Puerto Cabezas. 12 months ago, they formed a solidarity group with the intention of working together to get access to loans from Pana Pana. They also wanted to have the opportunity to improve their small seafood selling businesses, raise their incomes, and in that way improve the quality of life of their families. They decided to name the solidarity group "Gasparin" in honor of an angel.

Beksi is a member of the solidarity group "Gasparin." She is 24 years old and married with three children: two adolescents in primary school and a newborn. Her husband works informally as a mason. She established a small grocery store to have her own source of income and to contribute to the household expenses and to her children’s education. She sells supplies in an area in one of the markets in Bilwi. She’s requesting funding to diversify her business and to sell fish and shellfish. She dreams of having a variety.

loans.use: to buy fish and shellfish

loans.name: El Paraiso Group

texts.es:
Es un grupo solidario mixto, está conformado por 2 mujeres y un hombre emprendedor (Mariana, Derlin y Anastasio), pertenecen a la etnia miskita, del municipio de Puerto Cabezas. Se unieron hace 2 meses con el propósito de trabajar de manera solidaria para acceder a préstamos en Pana Pana,  para tener la oportunidad de mejorar sus pequeños negocios de venta de granos básicos, incrementar sus ingresos y así mejorar la calidad de vida de sus familias.Decidieron nombrar al Grupo Solidario El Paraíso, en honor a la capilla de la iglesia que visitan.

Anastacio: Es el coordinador del grupo solidario, es un señor jovial y luchador, casado con 4 hijos adolescentes que estudian su secundaria. Con el propósito de tener su propia fuente de ingresos y sacar adelante a su familia estableció una pequeña pulpería en su vivienda de tambo y madera. Esta solicitando financiamiento para comprar: Granos násicos, chiverías, entre otros productos. Sueña con tener un negocio prospero.
texts.en:
This is a mixed loan group. It is made up of 2 women and an enterprising man (Mariana, Derlin and Anastasio). They belong to the Miskito ethnicity, from the town of Puerto Cabezas. They got together 2 months ago with the purpose of working integrally to access loans with Pana Pana, to have the opportunity to improve their small businesses selling basic grains, increase their income, and, therefore, improve their families' quality of life. They decided to name the group "El Paraíso (The Paradise)" in honor of the chapel of the church they go to.

Anastasio is the coordinator of the group. He is young, cheerful, and determined. He is married with 4 young children who are in secondary school. With the purpose of having his own income and supporting his family, he established a small grocery store in his stilt and wood home. He is asking for funding to buy basic grains, snacks, and other products. He dreams of having a prosperous business.

loans.use: to buy basic grains, snacks, and other products.

loans.name: Micah

texts.en:
Micah is a Babban Gona farmer from Kargo Village. He joined Babban Gona so that he could realise better yields on his farm. 

Since joining Babban Gona, Micah no longer has to worry about having inadequate income to feed his family and children. Through Babban Gona’s input loan he will have access to top of the range farm inputs such as fertilisers, herbicides and improved seeds that will help him earn yields of up to 30 bags of maize/ hectare, double the national average in Nigeria.  This will see increase him increase his income considerably.  This season Micah has ambitious plans to harvest 15 bags of maize. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Micah now has the opportunity to ensure that all his children get a post secondary education.

loans.use: To purchase improved farm inputs that will increase farmer’s yields
